lesson.name: Lesson 7.13: Graphing the Standard Form, Part 2

page.title: 7.13.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will work on activities that focus on the coefficient of the linear term, the \(b\) in \(ax^2+bx+c\), and how changes to it affect the graph. You will discover that adding a linear term to the squared term translates the graph in both horizontal and vertical directions. This understanding will show that writing an expression such as \(x^2+b\) in factored form can help us reason how to sketch the graph.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Explain how the \(b\) in \(ax^2+bx+c\) affects the graph of the equation.
  • Match equations given in standard and factored form with their graph.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 7.13.1: Equivalent Expressions
  • 7.13.2: The Linear Term in a Quadratic Expression
    • 7.13.2: Self Check
    • 7.13.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.13.3: Writing Equations that Represent a Graph
    • 7.13.3: Self Check
    • 7.13.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.13.4: Graphing Quadratic Equations

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 7.13.5: Practice
  • 7.13.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 7.13.1: Equivalent Expressions
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

  1. Complete each row with an equivalent expression in standard form or factored form.

Standard Form

Factored Form

\(x^2\)

a. _____

d. _____

\(x(x+9)\)

\(x^2-18x\)

b. _____

e. _____

\(x(6-x)\)

\(-x^2+10x\)

c. _____

f. _____

\(-x(x+2.75)\)

    1. What is the factored form of \(x^2\)?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x\cdot x\)


    1. What is the factored form of \(x^2-18x\)?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x(x-18)\)


    1. What is the factored form of \(-x^2+10x\)?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(-x(x-10)\) or \(x(-x+10)\) or \(x(10-x)\)


    1. What is the standard form of \(x(x+9)\)?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x^2+9x\)


    1. What is the standard form of \(x(6-x)\)?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(-x^2+6x\)


    1. What is the standard form of \(-x(x+2.75)\)?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(-x^2-2.75x\)


  1. What do the quadratic expressions in each column have in common (besides the fact that everything in the left column is in standard form and everything in the other column is in factored form)? Be prepared to share your observations.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

In the left column, all the expressions in standard form have a squared term and a linear term but no constant term, and the squared term has a coefficient of either 1 or -1. In the right column, one of the factors is just a variable whose coefficient is 1 or -1, and the other factor is either a sum or a difference.

page.title: 7.13.2: The Linear Term in a Quadratic Expression
page.contents:
Activity



  1. Use the graphing tool or technology outside the course. Graph \(y=x^2\), and then experiment with adding different linear terms (for example, \(x^2+4x\), \(x^2+20x\), \(x^2-50x\)). Record your observations.

Select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

The graph still looks like a quadratic function when adding a linear term but it "shifts" both horizontally and vertically. Adding a positive multiple of \(x\) to \(x^2\) shifts it down and to the left while adding a negative multiple of \(x\) shifts it down and to the right.

Use your observations from question 1 to answer questions 2–5 and complete the table.

equation

\(x\)-intercepts

\(x\)-coordinate of vertex

\(y=x^2+6x\)

2a. _____

2b. _____

\(y=x^2-10x\)

3a. _____

3b. _____

\(y=-x^2+50x\)

4a. _____

4b. _____

\(y=-x^2-36x\)

5a. _____

5b. _____

  1. Find the \(x\)-intercepts and the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex for the equation \(y=x^2+6x\).
    1. What are the \(x\)-intercepts for the equation \(y=x^2+6x\)?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\((0,0)\),\((-6,0)\)

    1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex for the equation \(y=x^2+6x\)?

Enter your answer here:

Correct! -3

The correct answer is -3.

  1. Find the \(x\)-intercepts and the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex for the equation \(y=x^2-10x\).
    1. What are the \(x\)-intercepts for the equation \(y=x^2-10x\)?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\((0,0)\),\((10,0)\)

    1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex for the equation \(y=x^2-10x\)?

Enter your answer here:

Correct! 5

The correct answer is 5.

  1. Find the \(x\)-intercepts and the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex for the equation \(y=-x^2+50x\).
    1. What are the \(x\)-intercepts for the equation \(y=-x^2+50x\)?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\((0,0)\),\((50,0)\)

    1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex for the equation \(y=-x^2+50x\)?

Enter your answer here:

Correct! 25

The correct answer is 25.

  1. Find the \(x\)-intercepts and the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex for the equation \(y=-x^2-36x\).
    1. Find the \(x\)-intercepts for the equation \(y=-x^2-36x\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\((0,0)\),\((-36,0)\)

    1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex for the equation \(y=-x^2-36x\)?

Enter your answer here:

Correct! -18

The correct answer is -18.

Some quadratic expressions have no linear terms. For questions 6–7, find the \(x\)-intercepts and the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph representing each equation:

\(y=x^2-25\)

\(y=x^2+16\)

(Note it is possible for the graph to not intersect the \(x\)-axis.) If you get stuck, try graphing the equations.

  1. Find the \(x\)-intercepts and the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex for the equation \(y=x^2-25\).
    1. What are the \(x\)-intercepts for the equation \(y=x^2-25\)?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\((5,0)\),\((-5,0)\)

    1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex for the equation \(y=x^2-25\)?

Enter your answer here:

Correct! 0

The correct answer is 0.

  1. Find the \(x\)-intercepts and the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex for the equation \(y=x^2+16\).
    1. What are the \(x\)-intercepts for the equation \(y=x^2+16\)?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

There are no \(x\)-intercepts.

    1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex for the equation \(y=x^2+16\) ?

Enter your answer here:

Correct! 0

The correct answer is 0.

page.title: 7.13.2: Self Check
page.contents: Find the \(x\)-coordinates of all of the \(x\)-intercepts of the function \(f(x)=x^2-5x\).

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is one of the \(x\)-intercepts, but there are two. Factor the expression, set each factor equal to zero, and solve. The answer is \(x = 0\), \(x = 5\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: In factored form, \(f(x)=x^2-5x=x(x-5)\). The factors equal 0 at these values.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is one of the \(x\)-intercepts, but there are two. Factor the expression, set each factor equal to zero, and solve. The answer is \(x = 0\), \(x = 5\).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: While \(x = 0\) is an \(x\)-intercept, \(x = -5\) is not. Factor \(f(x)=x^2-5x\). Watch the signs when setting each factor equal to zero and solving. The answer is \(x = 0\), \(x = 5\).

page.title: 7.13.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Quadratics Without Linear Terms

Example

Find the \(x\)-intercepts and the vertex for \(f(x)=x^2-4\).

Step 1
Write the function in factored form. Use difference of squares:

\(f(x)=x^2-4=(x-2)(x+2)\)

Step 2
Set each factor equal to 0.

\(x - 2 = 0\)
\(x = 2\)

\(x + 2 = 0\)
\(x = -2\)

The \(x\)-intercepts are \((2, 0)\) and \((-2, 0)\).

Step 3
Find the \(x\)-value in the middle of the two \(x\)-intercepts. This occurs at \(x = 0\). This is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex.

To find the point at the vertex, substitute into the function:
\(f(0)=0^2-4=-4\)

Vertex: \((0, -4)\)

Try It: Quadratics Without Linear Terms

Find the \(x\)-intercepts and the vertex for \(f(x)=x2-64\).

Write down your answers, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to find the \(x\)-intercepts and vertex of \(f(x)=x^2-64\):

Step 1
Write the function in factored form:
\(f(x)=x^2-64=(x-8)(x+8)\)

Step 2
Set each factor equal to 0.
\(x - 8 = 0\)
\(x = 8\)

\(x + 8 = 0\)
\(x = -8\)

The \(x\)-intercepts are at \((8, 0)\) and \((-8, 0)\).

The vertex is located halfway between the \(x\)-intercepts, at \(x = 0\).

Step 3
To find the point, substitute into \(f(x)=x^2-64\).

\(f(0)=0^2-64=-64\)

The vertex is at \((0, -64)\).

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.13.3: Writing Equations that Represent a Graph
page.contents:
Activity

Use the graphing tool or technology outside the course. Identify the function that matches each graph. Make sure your graph goes through all three points shown!

  1. Identify the function of Graph A.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(y=x^2\)


  1. Identify the function of Graph B.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(y=x^2-9\) or \(y=(x-3)(x+3)\)

  1. Identify the function of Graph C.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(y=(x+2)(x-3)\)

  1. Identify the function of Graph D.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(y=x(x+6)\)

  1. Identify the function of Graph E.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(y=-x^2+4\) or \(y=(-x+2)(x+2)\)

  1. Identify the function of Graph F.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(y=(x-2)(x-2)\) or \(y=x^2-4x+4\)

  1. Identify the function of Graph G.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(y=(-x-1)(x-3)\)

  1. Identify the function of Graph H.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(y=(x-1)(x-5)\)

  1. Identify the function of Graph I.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(y=2x^2\)

  1. Identify the function of Graph J.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(y=-0.25x^2\)

Video: Writing Equations that Represent a Quadratic Graph

Watch the following video to learn more about writing equations that represent a quadratic graph.

page.title: 7.13.3: Self Check
page.contents: Which equation describes the graph below?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The signs of the constants in the factors should be opposite signs as the \(x\)-intercepts. The answer is \(f(x) = (x - 3)(x + 4)\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: The \(x\)-intercepts are at 3 and -4 so the factors are \((x - 3)\) and \((x + 4)\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Factored form is based on the \(x\)-intercepts, not the vertex. The answer is \(f(x) = (x - 3)(x + 4)\).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The \(x\)-intercepts of this function are 0 and -3. \(x=0\) is not an \(x\)-intercept. Watch the signs when writing the factors from the intercepts. The answer is \(f(x) = (x - 3)(x + 4)\).

page.title: 7.13.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Writing Quadratic Equations from Graphs

Write an equation for the graph below:

First, locate the \(x\)-intercepts at \((-2,0)\) and \((4,0)\).
Next, write the factor for each \(x\)-intercept.

The factors that result in the given zeros are \((x + 2)\) and \((x - 4)\).
The equation for this quadratic function is \(f(x)=(x + 2)(x - 4)\).

Use graphing technology to check your answer.

Try It: Writing Quadratic Equations from Graphs

Write an equation for the graph below:

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to write an equation for the function graphed:

First, identify the \(x\)-intercepts: \(x = -6\), \(x = 2.\)
Next, write a factor for each zero:
\((x + 6)\) and \((x - 2)\)

The function in factored form is \(f(x)=(x + 6)(x - 2)\).

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.13.4: Graphing Quadratic Equations
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

  1. Consider the quadratic equation \(y=x^2-4x\). Consider the graph of the equation when answering questions a and b.
    1. Where are the \(x\)-intercepts located?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

The \(x\)-intercepts are at \(x=0\) and \(x=4\).

    1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex?

Enter your answer here. 

Correct! The vertex is halfway between the intercepts at \(x=2\).

The correct answer is 2. The vertex is halfway between the intercepts at \(x=2\).


  1. Here is a graph of \(y=x^2\).

Sketch this graph, then sketch a graph of \(y=x^2+5x\) on the same graph. Briefly explain how you know where to sketch the graph.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x^2+5x\) is equivalent to \(x(x+5)\), so the \(x\)-intercepts are at \(x=0\) and \(x=-5\). Calculate the vertex by finding the \(x\)-coordinate in between \(x = -5\) and \(x = 0\) which is \(x = -2.5\). Substitute \(x=-2.5\) into the equation to find the \(y\)-coordinate: \(y=(-2.5)2+5(-2.5)=-6.188\). The vertex is at \((-2.5, -6.188)\). The squared term has a positive coefficient so the graph opens upward. Adding a positive linear term to \(x^2\) shifts the graph down and to the left.

page.title: 7.13.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. Choose the quadratic equation that represents each graph.

Correct! \(y=x^2+x\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.13.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(y=x^2+x\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Correct! \(y=-x^2+2\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.13.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(y=-x^2+2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Correct! \(y=x^2-x\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.13.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(y=x^2-x\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Correct! \(y=x^2+3x\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.13.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(y=x^2+3x\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Without graphing the equations, answer questions 2–5 to complete the table.

3a. _____

3b. _____

\(y=-x^2+16x\)

4a. _____

4b. _____

\(y=-x^2-24x\)

5a. _____

5b. _____

Correct! \((0,0),(-12,0)\)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activities 7.13.2–7.13.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.!

The correct answer is: \((0,0),(-12,0)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex for the equation \(y=x^2+12x\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! -6

Try again. Why don't you go back to activities 7.13.2–7.13.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is -6. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Find the \(x\)-intercepts and the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex for the equation \(y=x^2-3x\).

Correct! \((0,0), (3,0)\)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activities 7.13.2–7.13.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: \((0,0), (3,0)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex for the equation \(y=x^2-3x\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 1.5

Try again. Why don't you go back to activities 7.13.2–7.13.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 1.5. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Find the \(x\)-intercepts and the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex for the equation \(y=-x^2+16x\).

    1. What are the \(x\)-intercepts for the equation \(y=-x^2+16x\)?

Correct! \((0,0), (16,0)\)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activities 7.13.2–7.13.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: \((0,0), (16,0)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex for the equation \(y=-x^2+16x\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 8

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.13.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 8. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Find the \(x\)-intercepts and the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex for the equation \(y=-x^2-24x\).

    1. What are the \(x\)-intercepts for the equation \(y=-x^2-24x\)?

Correct! \((0,0), (-24,0)\)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activities 7.13.3 and 7.13.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is:\((0,0), (-24,0)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex for the equation \(y=-x^2-24x\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! -12

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.13.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is -12. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Here is a graph that represents \(y=x^2\).

  1. Describe what would happen to the graph if the original equation were changed to \(y=x^2-6x\).

Correct! The graph would move to the right and down.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.13.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: The graph would move to the right and down. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Predict the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph if the original equation were changed to \(y=x^2-6x\).

Correct! \((0,0),(6,0)\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.13.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is:\((0,0),(6,0)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. In which quadrant is the vertex located if the original equation were changed to \(y=x^2-6x\)?

Correct! Fourth Quadrant

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.13.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: Fourth Quadrant. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Select two equations whose graph opens upward.

Correct! \(y=(2x−1)^2\), \(y=x^2−8x−7\)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.13.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answers are: \(y=(2x−1)^2\), \(y=x^2−8x−7\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Graph A

Correct! Graph A

The correct answer is: Graph A. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Correct! Graph B

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.13.2–7.13.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: Graph B. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Correct! Graph C

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.13.2–7.13.4. Are you using it the right way?

page.title: 7.13.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Explain how the \(b\) in \(ax^2+bx+c\) affects the graph of the equation.
  • Match equations given in standard and factored form with their graph.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 7.13.1: Equivalent Expressions
    • In this activity, you compared standard and factored forms of quadratic equations and made observations about the two types of forms.
  • 7.13.2: The Linear Term in a Quadratic Expression
    • In this activity, you looked at different quadratic equations of the form \(f(x)=x^2+bx\) and \(f(x)=x^2+c\) and identified the \(x\)-intercepts and vertex.
    • 7.13.2: Self Check
    • 7.13.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.13.3: Writing Equations that Represent a Graph
    • In this activity, you used graphing technology to find the equation that would graph a quadratic function through three given points.
    • 7.13.3: Self Check
    • 7:13.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.13.4: Graphing Quadratic Equations
    • In this activity, you graphed quadratic functions in different forms by identifying the \(x\)-intercepts and vertex.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 7.13.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
